results.title: Anansi the spider: a tale from the Ashanti
results.creator_credit: Gerald McDermott and Gerald McDermott Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “African folklore”.
Anansi is a folk hero of the Ashanti people of Ghana and is a spider with human qualities. In this tale he falls into a river and is swallowed by a fish. After his rescue another accident befalls him. Rescued again, Anansi wishes to reward his son who has helped him with the aid of a beautiful white globe. Nyame, the One god, resolves the dilemma for him by setting the globe in the sky: it is the moon. Animation by Vincent Bell and narrated by Athmani Magoma. Animation inspired by the sophisticated geometric forms of the Ashanti.

results.title: Analytical filtration
results.brief_description: One of a series of instructional films produced to assist science teachers to demonstrate laboratory techniques to large groups of students. The film covers, in complete detail, the various operations involved in the simple technique of analytical filtration.

results.title: Analysis of Agility Exercises
results.brief_description: Film based on the Board of Education Syllabus of Physical Training for Schools (1933). Children in the film were drawn from city and borough elementary school. Various physical training exercises are demonstrated including crouch jumps, cat springs, broad jumps, hop, step, and jump forward, backward rolls and cartwheels.

results.title: Analysis of a television commercial
results.creator_credit: Eric Halliday, AFTRS and Vass Contis
results.brief_description: Eric Halliday interviews Bruce Kerridge, producer of the Mining Industry Council commercials and Dr. Ian Mills, a La Trobe University lecturer who indicate reasons for the production of a commercial and a method for interpreting the same.

results.title: Analysing interaction No.1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Nell Smith, Open University and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows an interaction sequence between a young man (Russ) and an older woman (Angela) who meet at a party. This sequence is then analysed by seven different psychologists and sociologists who adapt different orientations. Three of the analyses are presented in the first part. Suitable for Mid-Upper Secondary School level.

results.title: Analysing characters
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
Literary characters of James Thurber, Bret Hart and Nathaniel Hawthorne some to life to explain themselves, and appear in dramatisations of famous stories. They rate themselves in terms of development and complexity, and invite judgement of their actions based on each author’s purpose in writing their story.

results.title: An unnecessary famine
results.creator_credit: Chris Bryer, Yorkshire Television, Peter Gordon and Ian McFarlane
results.brief_description: Using Sudan as an example, shows that the causes of hunger in developing nations are both natural and political. Considers the roles of the World Bank and the major economic powers in this situation

results.title: An Ordinary woman
results.brief_description: Jackie is 38 years old. She lives with John and they have two small children. Once she wanted to be an opera singer. Once she had a boyfriend called Paul who married someone else. Once she travelled overseas. In the Sixties she was in love with Charlie. In the Seventies she sang in a band. In the Eighties she makes scones with the kids. In the process of (re) presenting an ordinary woman’s life this film explores questions of identity, representation and truth.

results.title: An Ordinary half hour in the extraordinary life of Robin Beckett
results.brief_description: Produced originally for inclusion in the Melbourne University Architectural Student’s Revue, this witty satire denounces the conformity of modern urban society through the character of Robin Beckett, who lives in a rubbish bin and falls in line with other members of his social group. Reviews incidents of a day in his life. No credits available.

results.title: An Opera prepares: 'Eugene Onegin'
results.creator_credit: Lesley Hammond, Brian Bosisto, Bosisto Productions and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description: A film made for use in secondary schools, to show the work and preparation that is involved in staging an opera performance, in this case, “Eugene Onegin”. Shows both the behind-the-scenes preparations and a dress rehearsal. Features the South Australia Opera Company and music by the ABC Symphony Orchestra. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
